5 STATE OF MAINE 
6 HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 
7 U9TH LEGISLATURE 
8 FIRST REGULAR SESSION 
9 COMJv1ITTEE AMENDMENT "A" to H.P. 743, L.D. 1001, Bill, "An Act Making 
10 Unified Appropriations and Allocations for the Expenditures of State Goven1ment, 
11 General Fund and Other Funds, and Changing Certain Provisions of the Law Necessaiy 
12 to the Proper Operations of State Government for the Fiscal Years Ending June 30, 2019, . 
13 June 30, 2020 and June 30, 2021" 
14 Amend the bill by striking out everything after the title and inserting the following: 
15 'Emergency preamble. Whereas, acts and resolves of the Legislature do not 
16 become effective until 90 days after adjournment unless enacted as emergencies; and 
17 Whereas, the 90-day period may not terminate until after the beginning of the next 
18 fiscal year; and 
19 Whereas, certain obligations and expenses incident to the operation of state 
20 departments and institutions will become due and payable immediately; and 
21 Whereas, in the judgment of the Legislature, these facts create an emergency within 
22 the meaning of the Constitution of Maine and require the following legislation as 
23 immediately necessaiy for the preservation of the public peace, health and safety; now, 
24 therefore, 
25 Be it enacted by the People of the State of Maine as follows: 
26 PART A 
27 Sec. A-1. Appropriations and allocations. The following appropriations and 
28 allocations are made. 
29 ADMINISTRATIVE AND FINANCIAL SERVICES, DEPARTMENT OF

Specialist III position to a Public Service Manager II position.  8

Governmental Ethics and Election Practices - Commission on 0414  30 
Initiative: Provides funding for the approved range change of one Registration and 31 
Reporting Officer position from range 20 to range 25 and reallocates the position from 32 
66% Other Special  Revenue Funds and 34% General Fund to 73% Other Special 33 
Revenue Funds and 27% General Fund within the same program and transfers All Other 34 
to Personal Services to fund the range change. This approved range change has an 35 
effective date of March 30, 2018.  36

reallocates one Family Independence Program Manager position from 50% Other Special 33

costs.  36

Computer Crimes 0048  17

position, one Computer Forensic Analyst position and one State Police Detective position 19 
and provides funding for All Ot her in order to restructure the computer crimes unit to 20 
more effectively address the growing demand for digital forensic analysis and 21 
investigations of crimes involving advanced technological devices.  22

current grant f unding ends on September 30, 2019.  35

Sec. C -1.  20-A MRSA §15671, sub -§7, ¶B, as amended by PL 2017, c. 284, Pt. 3 
C, §19, is further amended to read:  4 
B.  The annual targets for the state share percentage of the statewide adjusted total 5 
cost of the components of essential programs and servi ces are as follows.  6 
(1)  For fiscal year 2005 -06, the target is 52.6%.  7 
(2)  For fiscal year 2006 -07, the target is 53.86%.  8 
(3)  For fiscal year 2007 -08, the target is 53.51%.  9 
(4)  For fiscal year 2008 -09, the target is 52.52%.  10 
(5) For fiscal year 2009 -10, the target is 48.93%.  11 
(6)  For fiscal year 2010 -11, the target is 45.84%.  12 
(7)  For fiscal year 2011 -12, the target is 46.02%.  13 
(8)  For fiscal year 2012 -13, the target is 45.87%.  14 
(9)  For fiscal year 2013 -14, the target is 47.29%.  15 
(10)  For fiscal year 2014 -15, the target is 46.80%.  16 
(11)  For fiscal year 2015 -16, the target is 47.54%.  17 
(12)  For fiscal year 2016 -17, the target is 48.14%.  18 
(13)  For fiscal year 2017 -18, the target is 49.14%.  19 
(14)  For fiscal year 2018 -19, the target is 50.14%  49.58% . 20 
(15)  For fiscal year 2019 -20, the target is 50.78%.  21

C, §20, is further amended to read:  23

of the total cost of funding public education from kindergarten to grade 12 including 25 
the cost of the components of essential programs and services plus the state 26 
contributions to the unfunded actuarial liabilities of the Maine Public Employees 27 
Retirement System that a re attributable to teachers, retired teachers' health insurance 28 
and retired teachers' life insurance are as follows.  29 
(1)  For fiscal year 2011 -12, the target is 49.47%.  30 
(2)  For fiscal year 2012 -13, the target is 49.35%.  31 SECTION TOTAL - ALL FUNDS  $260,531  $150,766

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  (3)  For fiscal year 2013 -14, the t arget is 50.44%.  1 
(4)  For fiscal year 2014 -15, the target is 50.13%.  2 
(5)  For fiscal year 2015 -16, the target is 50.08%.  3

Sec. C -3.  20-A MRSA §15671 -A, sub -§2, ¶B, as amended by PL 2017, c. 446, 8 
§1, is further amended to read:  9 
B.  For property tax years beginning on or after April 1, 2005, the  The commissioner 10 
shall calculate the full -value education mill rate that is required to raise the statewide 11 
total local share.  The full -value education mill rate is calculated for each fiscal year 12 
by dividing the applicable statewide total local share by the a pplicable statewide 13 
valuation.  The full -value education mill rate must decline over the period from fiscal 14 
year 2005 -06 to fiscal year 2008 -09 and may not exceed 9.0 mills in fiscal year 2005 - 15 
06 and may not exceed 8.0 mills in fiscal year 2008 -09.  The fu ll-value education mill 16 
rate must be applied according to section 15688, subsection 3 -A, paragraph A to 17 
determine a municipality's local cost share expectation.  Full-value education mill 18 
rates must be derived according to the following schedule.  19 
(1)  For the 2005 property tax year, the full -value education mill rate is the 20 
amount necessary to result in a 47.4% statewide total local share in fiscal year 21 
2005 -06. 22 
(2)  For the 2006 property tax year, the full -value education mill rate is the 23 
amount necessary to result in a 46.14% statewide total local share in fiscal year 24 
2006 -07. 25 
(3)  For the 2007 property tax year, the full -value education mill rate is the 26 
amount necessary to result in a 46.49% statewide total local share in fiscal year 27 
2007 -08. 28 
(4)  For the  2008 property tax year, the full -value education mill rate is the 29 
amount necessary to result in a 47.48% statewide total local share in fiscal year 30 
2008 -09. 31 
(4-A)  For the 2009 property tax year, the full -value education mill rate is the 32 
amount necessary to result in a 51.07% statewide total local share in fiscal year 33 
2009 -10. 34 
(4-B)  For the 2010 property tax year, the full -value education mill rate is the 35 
amount necessary to result in a 54.16% statewide total local share in fiscal year 36 
2010 -11. 37 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 743, L.D. 1001  
 
 Page 529 - 129LR2405(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  (4-C)  For  the 2011 property tax year, the full -value education mill rate is the 1 
amount necessary to result in a 53.98% statewide total local share in fiscal year 2 
2011 -12. 3 
(5)  For the 2012 property tax year, the full -value education mill rate is the 4 
amount necessar y to result in a 54.13% statewide total local share in fiscal year 5 
2012 -13. 6 
(6)  For the 2013 property tax year, the full -value education mill rate is the 7

2013 -14. 9

amount necessary to result in a 53.20% statewide total local share in fiscal year 11 
2014 -15. 12

amount necessary to result in a 52.46% statewide total local share in fiscal year 14 
2015 -16. 15

amount necessary to result in a 51.86% statewide total local share in fiscal year 17 
2016 -17. 18

amount necessary to result in a 50.50%  50.42%  statewide total local share in 23 
fiscal year 2018 -19. 24

education mill rate is the amount necessary to result in a 45% 49.22%  statewide 26

Sec. C -7.  Authorization of payments.  If the State's continued obligation for 21 
any indiv idual component contained in those sections of this Part that set the total cost of 22 
funding public education from kindergarten to grade 12 and the local and state 23 
contributions for that purpose exceeds the level of funding provided for that component, 24 
any unexpended balances occurring in other programs may be applied to avoid proration 25 
of payments for any individual component. Any unexpended balances from this Part may 26 
not lapse but must be carried forward for the same purpose.  27 
Sec. C -8.  Limit of State's o bligation.  Those sections of this Part that set the 28 
total cost of funding public education from kindergarten to grade 12 and the local and 29 
state contributions for that purpose may not be construed to require the State to provide 30 
payments that exceed the a ppropriation of funds for general purpose aid for local schools 31 
for the fiscal year beginning July 1, 2019 and ending June 30, 2020.  32

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  §3101.  Definitions  1 
As used in this chapter, unless the context otherwise indicates, the following terms 2 
have the following meanings.  3 
1.  Director.   "Director" means the Director of the Governor's Office of Policy 4 
Innovation  and Mana gement  the Future  established by section 3102.  5 
2.  Office.   "Office" means the Governor's Office of Policy Innovation  and 6 
Management  the Future  established by section 3102.  7 
Sec. D -7.  5 MRSA §3102, as amended by PL 2017, c. 284, Pt. GG, §4, is further 8 
amen ded to read:  9 
§3102.  Office established; purpose  10 
The Governor's Office of Policy Innovation  and Management  the Future  is 11 
established in the Executive Department to facilitate achievement of long -term state goals 12 
and objectives and identification and implem entation of opportunities to improve the 13 
efficiency and effectiveness of the performance of the functions of and delivery of 14 
services by State Government.  15 
Sec. D -8.  5 MRSA §3103, as enacted by PL 2011, c. 655, Pt. DD, §5 and affected 16 
by §24, is amended to  read:  17 
§3103.  Director  18 
The Director of the Governor's Office of Policy Innovation  and Management  the 19 
Future  is appointed by the Governor and serves at the pleasure of the Governor.  20

department needs, but not macroeconomic forecasting, which is the responsibility of the 24 
Governor's Office of Policy Innovatio n and Management  the Future .  The department 25 
shall gather, maintain and have access to all economic and other information necessary to 26 
the performance of its duties;  27

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  5.  Promoting economic development and resource conservation; assistance to 1 
host communities.   To the extent practicable within existing resources, the Department 2 
of Economic and Community Development, the Governor's Energy Office and the 3 
Governor's Offi ce of Policy Innovation  and Management  the Future  shall provide, upon 4 
the request of a host community, assistance for the purpose of helping the host 5 
community maximize the economic development and resource conservation benefits 6 
from tax payments and payme nts made pursuant to a community benefit agreement or a 7 
community benefits package in connection with expedited wind energy developments.  8 
As part of this assistance, the department and the Department of Economic and 9 
Community Development shall support hos t communities in identifying additional 10 
funding and developing regional economic and natural resource conservation strategies.  11 
Sec. D -17.  38 MRSA §484, sub -§10, as amended by PL 2011, c. 655, Pt. DD, 12 
§18 and affected by §24, is further amended to read:  13 
10.  Special provisions; wind energy development or offshore wind power 14 
project.  In the case of a grid -scale wind energy development, or an offshore wind power 15 
project with an aggregate generating capacity of 3 megawatts or more, the proposed 16 
generating fac ilities, as defined in Title 35 -A, section 3451, subsection 5:  17 
A.  Will be designed and sited to avoid unreasonable adverse shadow flicker effects;  18 
B.  Will be constructed with setbacks adequate to protect public safety.  In making a 19 
finding pursuant to th is paragraph, the department shall consider the recommendation 20 
of a professional, licensed civil engineer as well as any applicable setback 21 
recommended by a manufacturer of the generating facilities; and  22 
C.  Will provide significant tangible benefits as de termined pursuant to Title 35 -A, 23 
section 3454, if the development is an expedited wind energy development.  24 
The Department of Labor, the Governor's Office of Policy Innovation  and Management  25 
the Future , the Governor's Energy Office and the Public Utilities  Commission shall 26 
provide review comments if requested by the primary siting authority.  27 
For purposes of this subsection, "grid -scale wind energy development," "primary siting 28 
authority," "significant tangible benefits" and "expedited wind energy developmen t" have 29 
the same meanings as in Title 35 -A, section 3451.  30 
Sec. D -18.  Maine Revised Statutes amended; revision clause.    Wherever in 31 
the Maine Revised Statutes the words "Governor's Office of Policy and Management" 32 
appear or reference is made to that enti ty or those words, those words are amended to 33 
read or mean, as appropriate, "Governor's Office of Policy Innovation and the Future" 34 
and the Revisor of Statutes shall implement this revision when updating, publishing or 35 
republishing the statutes.  36 
Sec. D -19.  Rename Office of Policy and Management program.  37 
Notwithstanding any other provision of law, the Office of Policy and Management 38 
program within the Executive Department is renamed the Office of Policy Innovation and 39 
the Future program.  40

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  PART E  1 
Sec. E -1.  4 MRSA §1610 -L is enacted to read:  2 
§1610 -L.  Additional securities  3 
Notwithstanding any limitation on the amount of securities that may be issued 4 
pursuant to section 1606, subsection 2, the authority may issue additional securities in an 5 
amount not to excee d $55,000,000 outstanding at any one time for capital repairs and 6 
improvements to state -owned facilities and hazardous waste cleanup on state -owned 7 
properties.  8 
Sec. E -2.  Maine Governmental Facilities Authority; issuance of 9 
securities.  Pursuant to the Mai ne Revised Statutes, Title 4, section 1606, subsection 2 10 
and section 1610 -L, and notwithstanding the limitation contained in Title 4, section 1606, 11 
subsection 2 regarding the amount of securities that may be issued, the Maine 12 
Governmental Facilities Author ity is authorized to issue securities in its own name in an 13 
amount up to $55,000,000.  Proceeds must be used for the purpose of paying the costs 14 
associated with capital repairs and improvements to and construction of state -owned 15 
facilities and hazardous wa ste cleanup on state -owned properties as designated by the 16 
Commissioner of Administrative and Financial Services.  17 
PART F  18 
Sec. F -1.  5 MRSA §1710 -E, as amended by PL 2011, c. 655, Pt. I, §6 and 19 
affected by §11, is further amended to read:  20 
§1710 -E.  Revenue Forecasting Committee; established; membership  21 
There is established the Revenue Forecasting Committee, referred to in this chapter 22 
as the "committee," for the purpose of providing the Governor, the Legislature and the 23 
State Budget Officer with analyses, fi ndings and recommendations relating to the 24 
projection of revenues for the General Fund and the Highway Fund based on economic 25 
assumptions recommended by the Consensus Economic Forecasting Commission.  The 26 
committee includes the State Budget Officer, the As sociate Commissioner for Tax Policy, 27 
the State Economist, an economist on the faculty of the University of Maine System 28 
selected by the chancellor, the Director of the Office of Fiscal and Program Review and 29 
another member of the Legislature's nonpartisan staff familiar with revenue estimating 30 
issues appointed by the Legislative Council.   One of the 6 members must be selected by 31 
a majority vote of the committee members to serve as the chair of the committee.   32 
Beginning in calendar year 2019, the chair of t he committee must be designated by a 33 
majority vote of the 6 members, from among the Associate Commissioner for Tax Policy, 34 
the Director of the Office of Fiscal and Program Review, the State Economist, an 35 
economist on the faculty of the University of Maine System selected by the chancellor 36 
and another member of the Legislature's nonpartisan staff familiar with revenue 37 
estimating issues appointed by the Legislative Council.  The chair must be designated on 38 
a rotating basis and serves a 2 -year term.  39

Sec. G -13.  36 MRSA §194 -D is enacted to read:  38 
§194 -D.  Bac kground investigations  39 
1.  Definitions.  As used in this section, unless the context otherwise indicates, the 40 
following terms have the following meanings.  41 
A.  "Affected person" means a person who is:  42 
(1)  An applicant for employment with the bureau;  43 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 743, L.D. 1001  
 
 Page 543 - 129LR2405(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  (2)  A  contractor for the bureau, including the contractor's employees, 1 
subcontractors and subcontractors' employees, who provides or is assigned to 2 
provide services to the bureau under an identified contract. For the purposes of 3 
this subparagraph, "identified c ontract" means a contract that the assessor 4 
determines involves access or the substantial possibility of access to the bureau's 5 
information technology systems or to confidential tax information;  6 
(3)  A current employee of the bureau; or  7 
(4)  An employee or  contractor, including the contractor's respective employees, 8 
subcontractors and subcontractors' employees, of another state agency, if the 9 
assessor determines the employee's or contractor's duties involve access or the 10 
substantial possibility of access to  federal tax information obtained from the 11 
bureau.  12 
B.  "Confidential tax information" means any information the inspection or disclosure 13 
of which is limited or prohibited by section 191, including federal tax information.  14 
C.  "Federal tax information" mean s a return and return information as defined in the 15 
Code, Section 6103(b) that is received directly from the United States Internal 16 
Revenue Service or obtained through a United States Internal Revenue Service - 17 
authorized secondary source and that is subject  to the confidentiality protections and 18 
safeguarding requirements of the United States Internal Revenue Code and 19 
corresponding federal regulations and guidance. "Federal return information" does 20 
not include information in the possession of the State that i s obtained from sources 21 
wholly independent from the United States Internal Revenue Service.  22 
2.  Background investigation requirements.  The assessor shall perform 23 
background investigations for affected persons in accordance with this subsection.  24 
A.  As par t of the process of evaluating an affected person for employment with the 25 
bureau, a background investigation must be conducted before an offer of employment 26 
is extended.  27 
B.  A background investigation for an affected person assigned to provide services to 28 
the bureau under an identified contract must be conducted before that affected person 29 
begins providing services to the bureau, and at least once every 10 years, as long as 30 
the affected person continues providing services to the bureau.  31 
C.  As part of the p rocess of evaluating an affected person for continued employment 32 
with the bureau, a background investigation must be conducted at least once every 10 33 
years.  If an affected person has not been subject to a background investigation within 34 
10 years prior to the effective date of this section, a background investigation must be 35 
conducted within one year of the effective date of this section.  36 
D.  A background investigation for an employee or contractor of another state agency 37 
must be conducted before that affec ted person is provided access, or the substantial 38 
possibility of access, to federal tax information obtained from the bureau, and at least 39 
once every 10 years, as long as the affected person continues to have such access. 40 
However, if the assessor determine s that the affected person has been subject to a 41 
background investigation that satisfies the background investigation standards 42 
established by the United States Internal Revenue Service regarding access to federal 43 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 743, L.D.  1001  
 
 Page 544 - 129LR2405(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  tax information within the past 10 years, no further investigation is required under 1 
this subsection for the 10 -year period commencing at the time of the background 2 
investigation.  3 
The background investigation must include fingerprinting and obtaining national criminal 4 
history record information fr om the Federal Bureau of Investigation and must satisfy the 5 
background investigation standards established by the United States Internal Revenue 6 
Service regarding access to federal tax information.  7 
3.  Fingerprinting.  An affected person must consent to ha ving fingerprints taken for 8 
use in background investigations in accordance with this section.  The State Police shall 9 
take or cause to be taken the affected person's fingerprints and shall forward the 10 
fingerprints to the Department of Public Safety, Bureau  of State Police, State Bureau of 11 
Identification so that the State Bureau of Identification can conduct state and national 12 
criminal history record checks for the bureau.  The State Police may charge the bureau for 13 
the expenses incurred in processing state and national criminal history record checks.  14 
The full fee charged under this subsection must be deposited in a dedicated revenue 15 
account for the State Bureau of Identification with the purpose of paying costs associated 16 
with the maintenance and replacemen t of the criminal history record systems.  17 
4.  Confidentiality.  All information obtained by the assessor pursuant to this section 18 
is confidential and not a public record as defined in Title 1, section 402, subsection 3.  19 
The information must only be used f or making decisions regarding the suitability of an 20 
affected person for new or continued employment with the bureau, to provide services to 21 
the bureau under an identified contract or to access federal tax information obtained from 22 
the bureau.  23 
5.  Affected person's access to criminal history record information.  The bureau 24 
shall provide an affected person with access to information obtained pursuant to this 25 
section, if requested, by providing a paper copy of the criminal history record information 26 
directly t o the affected person, but only after the bureau confirms that the affected person 27 
is the subject of the record.  In addition, the bureau shall publish guidance on requesting 28 
such information from the Federal Bureau of Investigation.  29 
6.  Disqualifying offe nses; refusal to consent.  The assessor shall review the 30 
information obtained under this section and determine whether an affected person has a 31 
disqualifying offense that would prohibit authorizing that individual from accessing 32 
confidential tax informatio n or federal tax information.  If an affected person refuses to 33 
consent to the background investigation requirements under this section, that affected 34 
person is considered to have a disqualifying offense. If the affected person has a 35 
disqualifying offense:  36 
A.  The bureau may not employ or utilize that affected person in a position for which 37 
access to confidential tax information is required;  38 
B.  If the affected person is an employee of the bureau or is assigned to provide 39 
services to the bureau under an ide ntified contract and the assessor has authorized the 40 
affected person to access confidential tax information, the bureau shall terminate that 41 
affected person's access and may remove that affected person from any position that 42 
involves access, or the substan tial possibility of access, to confidential tax 43 
information.  If the affected person is an employee of the bureau, the bureau shall 44 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 743, L.D. 1001  
 
 Page 545 - 129LR2405(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  make a reasonable effort to retain that person as an employee in another position 1 
within the bureau that does not require ac cess to confidential tax information; and  2 
C.  If the affected person is an employee or contractor of another state agency, the 3 
assessor shall notify the other agency and the agency shall terminate the affected 4 
person's access, or substantial possibility of  access, to federal tax information and 5 
may remove that affected person from any position that involves such access. If the 6 
affected person is an employee of the agency, the agency shall make a reasonable 7 
effort to retain that person as an employee in anot her position that does not require 8 
access to federal tax information.  9

Sec. H -7.  Restriction on use of certain state -municipal revenue -sharing 14 
amounts in fiscal year 2019 -20.  Notwithstanding any provision of law or municipal 15 
charter to the contrary, if a municipality adopted a budget for its municipal fiscal year 16 
beginning in calendar year 2019 with the assumption that state -municipal revenue sharing 17 
would be based on the transfer to the Local Government Fund of a pe rcentage of the 18 
revenue -sharing tax base under the Maine Revised Statutes, Title 30 -A, section 5681, 19 
subsection 5 that is lower than the percentage of the revenue -sharing tax base required 20 
under this Part, the municipal officers for that municipality may u se the difference 21 
between the amount of revenue sharing assumed in preparing the budget and the actual 22 
revenue sharing received pursuant to this Part without the requirement of approval by a 23 
town meeting or a municipal referendum if the funds are used for the repair or 24 
maintenance of roads or bridges within the municipality or the direct reduction of the 25 
property tax mill rate.  26 
PART I  27 
Sec. I -1.  Salary adjustments for Maine Revenue Services employees.  The 28 
State Tax Assessor may implement a salary adjustmen t for the Department of 29 
Administrative and Financial Services, Maine Revenue Services employees in the job 30 
classifications of Tax Examiner, Tax Examiner II, Senior Tax Examiner and Tax Section 31 
Manager to be compensated at a rate determined in accordance wi th recruitment and 32 
retention adjustments authorized by the Maine Revised Statutes, Title 5, section 7065, 33 
subsection 2 -D, the amount of which is in addition to the regular rate of pay.  34 
Sec. I -2.  Costs to General Fund.  Costs to the General Fund due to sec tion 1 of 35 
this Part must be provided from the Salary Plan program, General Fund account in the 36 
Department of Administrative and Financial Services in an amount up to $850,000 for the 37 
fiscal year ending June 30, 2020 and in an amount up to $850,000 for the fiscal year 38 
ending June 30, 2021 to implement the salary adjustment in section 1 of this Part.  39

PART L  14 
Sec. L -1.  Voluntary employee incentive programs.   Notwithstanding the 15 
Maine Revised Statutes, Title 5, section 903, subsections 1 and 2 , the Commissioner of 16 
Administrative and Financial Services shall offer for use prior to July 1, 2021 special 17 
voluntary employee incentive programs for state employees, including a 50% workweek, 18 
flexible position staffing and time off without pay. Employee  participation in a voluntary 19 
employee incentive program is subject to the approval of the employee's appointing 20 
authority.  21 
Sec. L -2.  Continuation of group health insurance.   Notwithstanding the 22 
Maine Revised Statutes, Title 5, section 285, subsection 7 a nd Title 5, section 903, the 23 
State shall continue to pay health and dental insurance benefits for a state employee who 24 
applies prior to July 1, 2021 and is approved to participate in a voluntary employee 25 
incentive program under section 1 of this Part based  upon the scheduled workweek in 26 
effect prior to the employee's participation in the voluntary employee incentive program.  27 
Sec. L -3.  Continuation of group life insurance.   Notwithstanding the Maine 28 
Revised Statutes, Title 5, sections 903 and 18056 and the rules of the Maine Public 29 
Employees Retirement System, the life, accidental death and dismemberment, 30 
supplemental and dependent insurance amounts for a state employee who applies prior to 31 
July 1, 2021 and is approved to participate in a voluntary employee incentive program 32 
under section 1 of this Part are based upon the scheduled hours of the employee prior to 33 
the employee's participation in the voluntary employee incentive program.  34 
Sec. L -4.  General Fund savings.   Notwithstanding the Maine Revised Statute s, 35 
Title 5, section 1585, the State Budget Officer shall transfer the General Fund savings 36 
resulting from the voluntary employee incentive programs under section 1 of this Part to 37 
the General Fund Compensation and Benefit Plan account in the Department of 38 
Administrative and Financial Services. The State Budget Officer shall submit to the joint 39 
standing committee of the Legislature having jurisdiction over appropriations and 40 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 743, L.D. 1001  
 
 Page 549 - 129LR2405(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  financial affairs a report of the transferred amounts no later than January 15, 2021  for 1 
fiscal year 2019 -20 and no later than January 15, 2022 for fiscal year 2020 -21. 2 
Sec. L -5.  Lapsed balances.   Notwithstanding any provision of law to the 3 
contrary, $350,000 in fiscal year 2019 -20 and $350,000 in fiscal year 2020 -21 of savings 4 
identifie d from the voluntary employee incentive programs in this Part lapse to the 5 
General Fund.  6 
PART M  7 
Sec. M -1.  Carry balances; Debt Service - Government Facilities 8 
Authority.   Notwithstanding any provision of law to the contrary, the State Controller 9 
shall car ry any remaining balances in the Debt Service - Government Facilities Authority 10 
program in the Department of Administrative and Financial Services in each year of the 11 
2020 -2021 biennium into the following fiscal year.  12 
PART N  13 
Sec. N -1.  Attrition savings.   Notwithstanding any provision of law to the 14 
contrary, the attrition rate for the 2020 -2021 biennium is 5% for judicial branch and 15 
executive branch departments and agencies only. The attrition rate for subsequent biennia 16 
is 1.6%.  17 
Sec. N -2.  Calculation and  transfer; attrition savings.   The State Budget 18 
Officer shall calculate the amount of the savings in section 3 of this Part that applies 19 
against each General Fund account for all executive branch departments and agencies 20 
statewide and shall transfer the am ounts by financial order upon the approval of the 21 
Governor. These transfers are considered adjustments to appropriations in fiscal years 22 
2019 -20 and 2020 -21. The State Budget Officer shall submit to the Joint Standing 23 
Committee on Appropriations and Financ ial Affairs a report of the transferred amounts 24 
no later than September 1, 2020.  25 
Sec. N -3.  Appropriations and allocations.  The following appropriations and 26 
allocations are made.  27

PART P  7 
Sec. P -1.  Department of Administrative and Financial Services; lease - 8 
purchase authorization.   Pursuant  to the Maine Revised Statutes, Title 5, section 9 
1587, the Department of Administrative and Financial Services, in cooperation with the 10 
Treasurer of State, may enter into financing agreements in fiscal years 2019 -20 and 2020 - 11 
21 for the acquisition of motor  vehicles for the Central Fleet Management Division. The 12 
financing agreements entered into in each fiscal year may not exceed $5,500,000 in 13 
principal costs, and a financing agreement may not exceed 4 years in duration. The 14 
interest rate may not exceed 5%. The annual principal and interest costs must be paid 15 
from the appropriate line category allocations in the Central Fleet Management Division 16 
account.  17 
PART Q  18

Department of Public Safety; lea se-purchase authorization for motor vehicles 20 
for State Police.   Pursuant to the Maine Revised Statutes, Title 5, section 1587, the 21 
Department of Administrative and Financial Services, in cooperation with the Treasurer 22 
of State, on behalf of the Department of Public Safety, may enter into financing 23 
agreements in fiscal years 2019 -20 and 2020 -21 for the acquisition of motor vehicles for 24 
the State Police. The financing agreements entered into in each fiscal year may not 25 
exceed $2,300,000 in principal costs, an d a financing agreement may not exceed 3 years 26 
in duration. The interest rate may not exceed 5%. The annual principal and interest costs 27 
must be paid from the appropriate line category appropriations and allocations in the 28 
State Police accounts.  29

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 743, L.D.  1001  
 
 Page 554 - 129LR2405(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  §1825.  Administer certain funds  1 
The bureau shall administer funds relating to state parks and historic sites, municipal 2 
recreation and recreation management on lands classified as state parks or historic sites 3 
pursuant to this chap ter. These funds include but are not limited to the following:  4 
1.  Maine State Parks and Recreational Facilities Development Fund.   The Maine 5 
State Parks and Recreational Facilities Development Fund is established within the 6 
bureau for the purpose of devel oping, maintaining and managing state parks and other 7 
recreational facilities on lands owned or leased by the bureau.  8 
Income from legislative appropriation, gifts, grants, bequests and other sources approved 9 
by the Legislature may be deposited into this fu nd.  Any interest earned on money in the 10 
fund must also be credited to the fund.  The Maine State Parks and Recreational Facilities 11 
Development Fund is nonlapsing and all funds are subject to allocation by the 12 
Legislature.  13 
1-A.  Parks General Operations Fu nd. The Parks General Operations Fund is 14 
established within the bureau for the purpose of developing, maintaining and managing 15 
state parks and other recreational facilities on lands owned or leased by the bureau.  16 
Income from legislative appropriation, gift s, grants, bequests, the Maine Environmental 17 
Trust Fund in accordance with section 10255, subsection 3 and any other sources 18 
approved by the Legislature may be deposited in this fund.  Any interest earned on money 19 
in the fund must be credited to the fund. The Parks General Operations Fund is 20 
nonlapsing and all funds are subject to allocation by the Legislature.  21 
2.  Maine State Parks Fund.   The Maine State Parks Fund is established within the 22 
bureau.  The fund receives money from the Maine Environmental Trus t Fund in 23 
accordance with section 10255, subsection 3.  The bureau shall use money in the fund for 24 
major and minor capital improvements, maintenance, repairs and operations at state parks 25 
and historic sites.  26 
The Maine State Parks Fund is nonlapsing and all  funds are subject to allocation by the 27 
Legislature.  28 
3.  Municipal Recreation Fund.   The bureau shall administer a state grant -in-aid 29 
fund known as the Municipal Recreation Fund.  The bureau is responsible for 30 
administering all money made available to the fund. Grants -in-aid may be made by the 31 
bureau out of the fund as follows.  32 
A.  The bureau may make grants to assist municipalities and other political 33 
subdivisions in the capital improvement of public park and recreation facilities for 34 
projects the total co st of each one of which does not exceed $5,000.  Such a grant 35 
may not exceed 75% of the approved project cost.  A municipality may not receive 36 
more than one grant under this paragraph in any fiscal year.  37 
B.  For those projects that are approved to receive federal financial assistance under 38 
the Federal  federal  Land and Water Conservation Fund Act of 1965,  (P.L.  Public 39 
Law 88-578) , as amended, the bureau may make a supplemental grant not to exceed 40 
40% of the approved project cost.  41 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 743, L.D. 1001  
 
 Page 555 - 129LR2405(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  C.  The bureau may make gr ants to assist municipalities and other political 1 
subdivisions in the development and implementation of recreation programs. Eligible 2 
costs for the program grants include, but are not limited to, employment of personnel, 3 
transportation and noncapital equip ment or supplies. Any grant made under this 4 
paragraph in any single fiscal year may not exceed $1,000 or 50% of the project cost, 5 
whichever is less.  6 
Funds credited to the Municipal Recreation Fund are nonlapsing.  7 
4.  Forest Recreation Resource Fund.   The b ureau may construct and maintain 8 
public campsites to prevent forest fires by providing fire -safe sites and preventing a 9 
proliferation of private fires and to provide recreation opportunities on lands within its 10 
jurisdiction and elsewhere in the State's for ests where there is inadequate provision of 11 
private, primitive campsites.  12 
For the purpose of carrying out these activities, the bureau may accept voluntary services 13 
and other contributions pursuant to this chapter; enter into leases and other agreements; 14 
and, pursuant to Title 5, chapter 375, subchapter II 2-A, establish rules and a schedule of 15 
fees for the use of these campsites.  All such fees and other revenues derived from grants, 16 
contributions, contracts and transfers to carry out the purposes of this subsection must be 17 
deposited in a nonlapsing account, to be called the Forest Recreation Resource Fund, 18 
which is a separate unit within the Parks General Operations Fund  to be used for the 19 
purposes of this subsection.  All funds in this account are subject  to allocation by the 20 
Legislature.  21 
5.  State Parks Improvement Fund established; sale of merchandise. The State 22 
Parks Improvement Fund, referred to in this section as "the fund," is established within 23 
the bureau.  The fund is nonlapsing and is a separate u nit within the Parks General 24 
Operations program .  The bureau may sell within parks or historic sites general 25 
merchandise that is distinctive to the parks or historic sites or useful to the enjoyment of 26 
the parks or historic sites.  Items that may be sold i nclude, but are not limited to, hats, 27 
coffee mugs, bumper stickers, t -shirts, tote bags and firewood.  Merchandise sold by the 28 
bureau must be of good quality, appropriate for sale by the bureau and sold for a 29 
reasonable fee. The bureau also may rent items to be used for the enjoyment of the park 30 
or historic site, including, but not limited to, rowboats, canoes, kayaks and bicycles.  To 31 
the extent the bureau needs to contract with vendors to obtain goods or services in order 32 
to develop, create or manufacture  merchandise for sale or lease, the commissioner shall, 33 
to the maximum extent practicable, contract with vendors located in this State.  Goods 34 
and services purchased by the bureau for sale or lease under this section must be procured 35 
in accordance with Tit le 5, chapter 155.  All proceeds from the sale or lease of 36 
merchandise pursuant to this subsection must be deposited in the fund and used for the 37 
operation and maintenance of parks.  38

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  PART MM  1 
Sec. MM -1.  Department of Corrections; transfer of funds for overtime 2 
expenses.   Notwithstanding the Maine Revised Statutes,  Title 5, section 1585 or any 3 
provision of law to the contrary, the Department of Corrections, by financial order upon 4 
the recommendation of the State Budget Officer and approval of the Governor, may 5 
transfer Personal Services, All Other or Capital Expendi tures funding between accounts 6 
within the same fund for the purposes of paying overtime expenses in fiscal years 2019 - 7 
20 and 2020 -21. These transfers are not considered adjustments to appropriations.  8 
PART NN  9 
Sec. NN -1.  Transfers and adjustments to positio n count.   The Commissioner 10 
of Corrections shall review the current organizational structure of the Department of 11 
Corrections to improve organizational efficiency and cost -effectiveness and shall 12 
recommend transfers of positions and available balances.  Not withstanding any provision 13 
of law to the contrary, the State Budget Officer shall transfer the position counts and 14 
available balances by financial order, in order to achieve the purposes of this section, 15 
from July 1st to December 1st of each fiscal year of  the 2020 -2021 biennium.  Position 16 
adjustments made after December 1st and before July 1st of each fiscal year may not be 17 
considered an adjustment to position count or appropriations.  The transfer and 18 
adjustment authorized by this section must comply with  the requirements of the Maine 19 
Revised Statutes, Title 5, section 1585.  Any transfer or adjustment pursuant to this 20 
section that would result in a program or mission change or facility closure must be 21 
reported by the Bureau of the Budget to the joint stan ding committee of the Legislature 22 
having jurisdiction over criminal justice and public safety matters for review before the 23 
associated financial order is submitted to the Governor for approval; these transfers are 24 
considered adjustments to authorized posit ion count, appropriations and allocations.  25

Sec. UU -3.  20-A MRSA §15689, sub -§7-A is enacted to read:  10 
7-A.  Adjustment for minimum teacher salary.   Beginning in fiscal year 2020 -21, 11 
the commissioner shall, in accordance with this subsection, increase the state share of the 12 
total allocation to a qualifying school administrative unit by an amount necessary to 13 
achieve the minimum salary for certified teachers established in section 13407.  14 
A.  As used in this subsection, unless the context otherwise indicates,  "qualifying 15 
school administrative unit" means a school administrative unit that the commissioner 16 
determines to have a locally established salary schedule with a minimum teacher 17 
salary of less than $40,000 in school year 2019 -2020. As used in this subsecti on, 18

incremental increases in the salaries of teachers employed by a qualifying school 20 
administrative unit in school year 2019 -2020 necessary to meet the minimum salary 21 
require ments of section 13407 from fiscal year 2020 -21 to fiscal year 2022 -23. 22 
B.  The commissioner shall allocate the funds appropriated by the Legislature in 23 
accordance with the following.  24 
(1)  The amount of increased funds provided to qualifying school adminis trative 25 
units under this subsection must be the amount necessary to fund the incremental 26 
salary increases specified in this subsection.  27

qualifying school administrative unit for a fi scal year must be based on the 29 
information supplied to the department pursuant to section 13407 in that fiscal 30 
year.  31

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  PART VV  1 
Sec. VV -1.  Lease -purchase authorization; Department of Ed ucation's 2 
learning technology program.   Pursuant to the Maine Revised Statutes, Title 5, 3 
section 1587, the Department of Education may enter into financing arrangements in 4 
fiscal years 2019 -20 and 2020 -21 for the acquisition of portable learning devices an d 5 
support systems for students and educators to support the operations of the department's 6 
learning technology program. The financing agreements may not exceed 4 years in 7 
duration and $50,000,000 in principal costs for the department's learning technology 8 
program. The interest rate may not exceed 8%, and the total interest costs may not exceed 9 
$4,000,000. The annual principal and interest costs must be paid from the appropriate line 10 
category allocations in the Department of Education. The State is authorize d to extend the 11 
provisions of the lease -purchase agreement on behalf of school administrative units as 12 
long as all costs of the extension are borne by the school administrative units.  13

Sec. EEE -1.  36 MRSA §2892, as amended by PL 2017, c. 284, Pt. IIII, §1, is 20 
further amended to read:  21 
§2892.  Tax imposed  22 
For the state fiscal year beginning on July 1, 2003, a tax is imposed against each 23 
hospital in th e State.  The tax is equal to .74% of net operating revenue for the tax year as 24 
identified on the hospital's most recent audited annual financial statement for that tax 25 
year.  Delinquent tax payments are subject to Title 22, section 3175 -C. 26 
For state fisca l years beginning on or after July 1, 2004, a tax is imposed annually 27 
against each hospital in the State.  The tax is equal to 2.23% of the hospital's net 28 
operating revenue as identified in the hospital's audited financial statement for the 29 
hospital's taxa ble year.  For the state fiscal year beginning July 1, 2004, the hospital's 30 
taxable year is the hospital's fiscal year that ended during calendar year 2002.  For the 31 
state fiscal year beginning July 1, 2005, the hospital's taxable year is the hospital's fi scal 32 
year that ended during calendar year 2003.  For state fiscal years beginning on or after 33 
July 1, 2006 but before July 1, 2008, the hospital's taxable year is the hospital's fiscal year 34 
that ended during calendar year 2004.  35 
For state fiscal years begin ning on or after July 1, 2008 but before July 1, 2010 , the 36 
hospital's taxable year is the hospital's fiscal year that ended during calendar year 2006.  37 
For state fiscal years beginning on or after July 1, 2010 but before July 1, 2013 , the 38 
hospital's taxable  year is the hospital's fiscal year that ended during calendar year 2008.  39 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 743, L.D. 1001  
 
 Page 571 - 129LR2405(02) -1

hospital's taxable year is the hospital's fiscal year that ended during calendar year 2012.  2

hospital's taxable year is the hospital's fiscal year that ended during calendar year 2014.  4

Share - Riverview Ps ychiatric Center program and the Riverview Psychiatric Center 6 
program after all salary, benefit and other obligations are met to the All Other line 7 
category of those programs. These amounts may be transferred by financial order upon 8

transfers are not considered adjustments to appropriations.  10

PART JJJ  20 
Sec. JJJ -1.  Emergency rule -making authority; health and human 21 
services matters.   The Department of Health and Human Services is authorized to 22 
adopt emergency rules under the Maine Revised Statutes, Title 5, sections 8054 and 8073 23 
as necessary to implement those provisions of this Act over which the department has 24 
subject matter jurisdiction for which specific authority has not been provided in any other 25 
Part of this Act without the necessity of demonstrating that immediate adoption is 26 
necessary to avoid a t hreat to public health, safety or general welfare.  27 
PART KKK  28 
Sec. KKK -1.  Study of the new Medicaid expansion population.   The 29 
Department of Health and Human Services shall conduct a study of the population 30 
covered under the expansion of Medicaid.  The depa rtment, as part of the study, shall 31 
examine the per capita cost of enrollees; changes in uncompensated care; reimbursement 32 
rates and revenue from Medicaid compared to other payers; value -based purchasing 33 
options; previous insurance status of new members; t he impact of the expansion on 34 
private insurers and the economy; and any other element necessary to inform future 35 
policy decisions by the department.  The department shall fund this study within existing 36 
resources.  37

PART QQQ  28 
Sec. QQQ -1.  5 MRSA §7054 -C, as enacted by PL 2017, c. 261, §1, is amended 29 
to read:  30 
§7054 -C.  Person with disability preference  31 
1.  Definitions.  As used in this section, unless the context otherwise indicates, the 32 
following terms have the following meaning s. 33 
A.  "Person with a disability" means a person who has been determined by a qualified 34 
professional to have a physical or mental impairment that constitutes a substantial 35 
barrier to employment but who can benefit in terms of an employment outcome from 36 
the provision of vocational rehabilitation services  a physical or mental impairment 37 
that substantially limits one or more of the person's major life activities . 38 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 743, L.D. 1001  
 
 Page 575 - 129LR2405(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  B.  "Qualified professional" means a vocational rehabilitation counselor or other 1 
professional wit h advanced disability training and certification.  2 
C.  "Special appointment program" means the program established by rule by the 3 
Department of Administrative and Financial Services, Bureau of Human Resources to 4 
provide persons with disabilities increased a ccess to positions in the classified 5 
service.  6 
D.  "Ticket to Work program" means the Ticket to Work and Self -Sufficiency 7 
Program under Section 1148 of the federal Social Security Act.  8 
2.  Interview.  In filling a position in the classified service, the emp loying agency 9 
shall offer an interview to a person with a disability who is eligible for the Ticket to Work 10 
program and  who meets the minimum qualifications established for the position and to a 11 
person who has been determined by a qualified professional to  have a disability and who 12 
meets the minimum qualifications established for the position . 13 
3.  Guidance and referral if not hired.  If a person with a disability applies for a 14 
position described in subsection 2 but is not selected, the Department of Adminis trative 15 
and Financial Services, Bureau of Human Resources shall provide guidance to the person 16 
regarding other available state positions , including opportunities in the special 17 
appointment program,  for which the person might qualify.  The Bureau of Human 18 
Resources may also refer the person to the Department of Labor, Bureau of Rehabilitation 19 
Services for potential vocational rehabilitation services if the person has not been referred 20 
by a qualified professional , including opportunities in the special appoin tment program . 21 
4.  Retention preference.  In any reduction in personnel in the state service, 22 
employees who are eligible for the Ticket to Work program or who are  persons with 23 
disabilities must be retained in preference to all other competing employees in the same 24 
classification with equal seniority, status and performance reviews.  25 
5.  Right to nondisclosure.  A person with a disability or who is eligible for the 26 
Ticket to Work program  has the right to not disclose that person's disability at the time of 27 
hire but may not assert a right to a retention preference pursuant to subsection 4 at a later 28 
date.  29

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  PART SSS  1 
Sec. SSS -1.  Waiver for state innovation.  The Commissioner of Health and 2 
Human Se rvices in consultation with the Superintendent of Insurance may apply to the 3 
United States Secretary of Health and Human Services under 42 United States Code, 4 
Section 18052 for a waiver of applicable provisions of the federal Patient Protection and 5 
Afforda ble Care Act with respect to health insurance coverage in the State for a plan year 6 
beginning on or after January 1, 2021 for the purposes of improving affordability.  The 7 
commissioner may implement a state plan meeting the waiver requirements in a manner 8 
consistent with state and federal law and as approved by the United States Secretary of 9 
Health and Human Services.  The state plan may not increase cost sharing or reduce the 10 
comprehensiveness of coverage.  If a waiver application has not been submitted by  June 11 
30, 2022, the authority to apply for a waiver pursuant to this section is terminated.  12

PART EEEE  12 
Sec. EEEE -1.  Personal Services review.  The Department of Administrative 13 
and Financial Services, Bureau of the Budget shall conduct a review of Personal Services 14 
balances in executive branch departments and agencies for the purpose of identifying 15 
total General Fund savings in the Personal Services line category equal to $1,046,580 and 16 
Highway Fund savings in the Personal Services line category equal to $31,578 in fiscal 17 
years 2018 -19, 2019 -20 and 2020 -21. 18 
Sec. EEEE -2.  Calculation and transfer. Notwithstanding any pr ovision of law 19 
to the contrary, the State Budget Officer shall calculate the amount of the savings 20 
associated with section 1 of this Part that applies against each General Fund and Highway 21 
Fund account for all executive branch departments and agencies stat ewide and shall 22 
transfer the amounts by financial order upon the approval of the Governor. These 23 
transfers are considered adjustments to appropriations in fiscal years 2018 -19, 2019 -20 24 
and 2020 -21. 25

and allocations are made.  27

Sec. IIII -8.  30-A MRSA §5250 -O, first ¶, as amended by PL 2017, c. 440, §4, 8 
is further amended to read:  9 
A business may apply to the commissioner f or certification as a qualified Pine Tree 10 
Development Zone business.  Upon review and determination by the commissioner that a 11 
business is a qualified Pine Tree Development Zone business, the commissioner shall 12 
issue a letter of certification to the busine ss that includes a description of the qualified 13 
business activity for which the letter is being issued.  Prior to issuing a letter of 14 
certification, the commissioner must find that the business activity will not result in a 15 
substantial detriment to existin g businesses in the State.  In order to make this 16 
determination, the commissioner shall consider those factors the commissioner 17 
determines necessary to measure and evaluate the effect of the proposed business activity 18 
on existing businesses, including whet her any adverse economic effect of the proposed 19 
business activity on existing businesses is outweighed by the contribution to the 20 
economic well -being of the State.  The State Economist must review applications under 21 
this section and provide an advisory opi nion to assist the commissioner in making 22 
findings under this section.   The commissioner shall provide a copy of the letter of 23 
certification to the State Tax Assessor.  24

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  10.  Special provisions; wind energy development or offshore wind power 1 
project.  In the case of a grid -scale wind energy development, or an off shore wind power 2 
project with an aggregate generating capacity of 3 megawatts or more, the proposed 3 
generating facilities, as defined in Title 35 -A, section 3451, subsection 5:  4 
A.  Will be designed and sited to avoid unreasonable adverse shadow flicker eff ects; 5 
B.  Will be constructed with setbacks adequate to protect public safety.  In making a 6 
finding pursuant to this paragraph, the department shall consider the recommendation 7 
of a professional, licensed civil engineer as well as any applicable setback 8 
recommended by a manufacturer of the generating facilities; and  9 
C.  Will provide significant tangible benefits as determined pursuant to Title 35 -A, 10 
section 3454, if the development is an expedited wind energy development.  11 
The Department of Labor, the Gover nor's Office of Policy and Management,  the 12 
Governor's Energy Office and the Public Utilities Commission shall provide review 13 
comments if requested by the primary siting authority.  14 
For purposes of this subsection, "grid -scale wind energy development," "prim ary siting 15 
authority," "significant tangible benefits" and "expedited wind energy development" have 16 
the same meanings as in Title 35 -A, section 3451.  17

referred to in this subch apter as "the superintendent," and is responsible to the 10 
commissioner.  11

PART RRRR  11 
Sec. RRRR -1.  Strategic economic plan.  The Department of Economic and 12 
Community Development, in collaboration with public and private constituents, shall 13 
facilitate the creation of a 10 -year strategic economic plan, referred to in this section as  14 
"the strategic plan," that recommends breakthrough strategies for increased economic 15 
prosperity for all citizens of the State in all regions, ultimately measured by increased 16 
household income, a growing workforce and sustainable business development.  17 
The strategic plan must extend broadly from the Maine Innovation Economy 18 
Advisory Board's 2017 innovation economy action plan created pursuant to the Maine 19 
Revised Statutes, Title 10, section 949 and seek to leverage private and federal 20 
investment, particularl y in areas of scientific research and commercialization.  The 21 
strategic plan's strategic goals must include the following:  22 
1.  To drive the value -added contribution per job from $87,160 to a goal identified by 23 
the Department of Economic and Community Devel opment;  24 
2.  To equitably grow the annual median wage per job from $31,550 to a goal 25 
identified by the Department of Economic and Community Development; and  26 
3.  To grow the workforce from 700,000 workers to a goal identified by the 27 
Department of Economic an d Community Development.  28 
The strategic plan must include sufficient assignments of accountability to ensure 29 
execution of the plan with sufficient metrics for effective management.  30 
The strategic plan must include an analysis of gaps in funding and policy an d 31 
recommendations that ensure dependable continuity of access to capital across business 32 
start-up stages from equity investments, seed capital tax credits, start -up grants and direct, 33 
revolving and commercial loans with clear benchmarks, rigorous accountab ility, public 34 
transparency and risk mitigation that protect public benefits.  35 
Following a comprehensive assessment and trend analysis of research and 36 
development and business and commercial assets in the State, the Department of 37 
Economic and Community Devel opment shall ensure that the strategic plan includes 38 
consideration of but is not limited to directing policy supports that suit economic 39 
development in the emerging sectors of: life sciences and biomedical technology, 40 
environmental and renewable energy tec hnology, information technology, advanced 41 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 743, L.D.  1001  
 
 Page 592 - 129LR2405(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  technologies for forestry and agriculture, aquaculture and marine technology, composites 1 
and advanced materials and precision manufacturing.  2 
The strategic plan must complement and support other concurrent and paral lel state 3 
planning initiatives on energy and broadband connectivity such as the comprehensive 4 
state energy plan pursuant to the Maine Revised Statutes, Title 2, section 9, subsection 3, 5 
paragraph C, the Statewide Broadband Action Plan of the Department of Economic and 6 
Community Development dated March 2018 and the Detailed 2019 -2021 Strategic Plan 7 
for Broadband Service in Maine created by the ConnectME Authority in February 2019.  8 
The Department of Economic and Community Development shall establish a steerin g 9 
committee composed of representatives from the Department of Economic and 10 
Community Development, the Finance Authority of Maine and the Department of Labor 11 
and the State Economist; the steering committee shall guide the development of the 12 
strategic plan.  13 
The Department of Economic and Community Development shall establish a work 14 
team, and the work team shall develop the content of the strategic plan.  The work team 15 
must include, but is not limited to, the members of the steering committee and 16 
representati ves from a state business organization, the Maine Technology Institute, the 17 
Maine Development Foundation, a venture capital fund operating in the State, the office 18 
of the President of the University of Maine and a state building and trades organization.  19 
The content of the strategic plan must be informed by the work team and developed 20 
in consultation with individuals and agencies, including, but not limited to, those with 21 
qualifications and experience related to: scientific research leading to creation of 22 
intellectual property, entrepreneurship and successful development of start -up and spin - 23 
off businesses; evaluating and underwriting successful business start -ups; technology 24 
transfer and capitalization of intellectual property; evaluating or completing succe ssful 25 
projects funded in partnership with institutions such as the National Science Foundation, 26 
the United States Department of Health and Human Services, the National Institutes of 27 
Health and National Institute of General Medical Sciences and the Maine Ex perimental 28 
Program to Stimulate Competitive Research, established in the Maine Revised Statutes, 29 
Title 5, section 13110, federal small business innovation research and small business 30 
technology transfer programs, national research laboratories and the Main e Technology 31 
Institute's technology asset fund.  32 
The strategic plan must also be informed by input from, without limitation, the 33 
Finance Authority of Maine, the Maine Technology Institute, the Governor's office of 34 
innovation and the future, the Department o f Economic and Community Development, 35 
the Maine Innovation Economy Advisory Board, the office of the President of the 36 
University of Maine, the office of the Chancellor of the University of Maine System, the 37 
ConnectME Authority, an organization representing  the energy sector, a venture capital 38 
fund operating in the State, organizations in the State dedicated to entrepreneurship, an 39 
organization in the State dedicated to biomedical research excellence and the State's 40 
congressional delegation.  41 
The Department o f Economic and Community Development shall establish within 42 
the strategic plan a schedule for periodic review of the plan goals and progress made 43 
pursuant to those goals.  The Department of Economic and Community Development 44 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 743, L.D. 1001  
 
 Page 593 - 129LR2405(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  shall also include within the s trategic plan a strategy for continuation of the strategic plan 1 
following the expiration of the 10 -year plan period.  2 
By December 31, 2019, the Department of Economic and Community Development 3 
shall provide a report on the strategic plan to the Joint Standi ng Committee on 4 
Appropriations and Financial Affairs and the Joint Standing Committee on Innovation, 5 
Development, Economic Advancement and Business and shall provide copies of the 6 
strategic plan to all members of the Legislature.  The Joint Standing Commit tee on 7 
Innovation, Development, Economic Advancement and Business may report out a bill 8 
based on the report to the Second Regular Session of the 129th Legislature.  9 
PART SSSS  10 
Sec. SSSS -1.  25 MRSA §2927, sub -§1-E, ¶A, as amended by PL 2009, c. 617, 11 
§8 and a ffected by §13, is repealed and the following enacted in its place:  12 
A.  Prior to January 1, 2020, the statewide E -9-1-1 surcharge is 45¢ per month per 13 
line or number. Beginning January 1, 2020, the Public Utilities Commission shall 14 
establish the statewide E-9-1-1 surcharge, except that the statewide E -9-1-1 surcharge 15 
may not exceed 35¢ per month per line or number.  The commission shall establish 16 
the statewide E -9-1-1 surcharge by routine technical rules, as defined in Title 5, 17 
chapter 375, subchapter 2 -A, or through other commission proceedings.  The 18 
statewide E -9-1-1 surcharge may not be imposed on more than 25 lines or numbers 19 
per customer billing account.  20

In accordanc e with the policy expressed in section 2, every school administrative unit 17 
shall raise annually sufficient funds to maintain or support elementary and secondary 18 
schools to provide free education for its resident students at all grade levels. These 19 
schools shall meet the requirements of basic school approval.  To the extent the State 20 
provides adequate start -up funding, a school administrative unit may offer an opportunity 21 
for every child 4 years of age residing in the school administrative unit to attend a p ublic 22 
preschool program, or a program affiliated with the school administrative unit, meeting 23 
the requirements of basic school approval.  It is the goal of the State to provide adequate 24 
start-up funding to ensure that public preschool programs for children  4 years of age are 25 
offered by all school administrative units by the 2018 -2019  2023 -2024  school year.  26

develop recommendations, including recommended legislation, for the implem entation of 31 
universal public preschool for children 4 years of age. The recommendations must 32 
include, but are not limited to:  33 
1.  Standards for public preschool programs;  34 
2.  A process for approval and certification of programs not operated by a school 35 
administrative unit, including, but not limited to, a Head Start program or other program 36 
affiliated with the school administrative unit; and  37

PART VVVV  9 
Sec. VVVV -1.  Legislature to contract for independent review of the 10 
State's early childhood special education services.   The Legislature, through the 11 
Joint Standing Committee on Education and Cultural Affairs, referred to in this Part as 12 
"the joint standing committee," may contract with a qual ified research and technical 13 
assistance entity to conduct pursuant to sections 5 and 6 an independent review of the 14 
State's early childhood special education services and develop recommendations and an 15 
implementation plan.  16 
Sec. VVVV -2.  Assistance; request  for proposals process.   At the direction of 17 
the joint standing committee, the Office of the Executive Director of the Legislative 18 
Council, referred to in this Part as "the office," shall develop and administer a request for 19 
proposals process to permit the  Legislature, through the joint standing committee, to 20 
award a contract pursuant to section 1.  The office, with the advice and assistance of the 21 
Independent Review Advisory Committee, established under section 4 and referred to in 22 
this Part as "the adviso ry committee," and in consultation with and with the approval of 23 
the joint standing committee, shall:  24 
1. Develop and administer a request for proposals process in accordance with section 25 
3; 26 
2. Administer the contract entered into pursuant to section 1, inc luding monitoring 27 
the research and technical assistance entity's performance in meeting deadlines, providing 28 
deliverables pursuant to sections 5 and 6 and complying with other terms of the contract; 29 
and 30 
3. Within available resources, provide other assistan ce to the joint standing 31 
committee relating to the contract and the purposes of this Part.  32 
Sec. VVVV -3.  Request for proposals; standards and selection process.   33 
The office, with the advice and assistance of the advisory committee, and in consultation 34 
with and with the approval of the joint standing committee, shall administer a request for 35 
proposals process in accordance with this section.  36 
1.  The qualifications of a research and technical assistance entity submitting a 37 
proposal must include, but are not l imited to, the financial, technical and operational 38 
capacity of the entity to conduct state -level education policy research and fiscal analysis, 39 
as demonstrated by the entity's professional experience and expertise.  40 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 743, L.D.  1001  
 
 Page 596 - 129LR2405(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  2.  With the approval of the joint stand ing committee, the office shall issue a request 1 
for proposals and publish notice of the request on the Legislature's publicly accessible 2 
website and through advertisements in 2 or more public newspapers circulated wholly or 3 
in part in the State and may pro vide any further notice of the request to any other media 4 
or entities, as approved by the joint standing committee. The notice must provide that the 5 
office will accept, for 30 days after the first date of publication, proposals from qualified 6 
research and technical assistance entities that meet the standards approved by the joint 7 
standing committee.  8 
3. After proposals have been received and the period for accepting proposals has 9 
expired, the office, with the advice and counsel of the advisory committee, sha ll evaluate 10 
the proposals and present a ranking of or recommendations regarding the proposals to the 11 
joint standing committee. The joint standing committee shall review the 12 
recommendations and choose the proposal it wishes to accept. The joint standing 13 
committee shall notify the Executive Director of the Legislative Council of its selection 14 
of a proposal. The executive director shall execute a contract with the selected research 15 
and technical assistance entity on behalf of the Legislature.  16 
4. Notwithstandin g the Maine Revised Statutes, Title 1, section 402, except for the 17 
name and mailing address of a research and technical assistance entity that submits a 18 
proposal, the proposal and all other materials prepared, used or submitted in connection 19 
with the propo sal are confidential and are not subject to public review until the period for 20 
accepting proposals has expired.  21 
Sec. VVVV -4.  Independent Review Advisory Committee.   The Independent 22 
Review Advisory Committee is established to advise the office and joint st anding 23 
committee on matters related to developing a request for proposals and administering the 24 
contract entered into pursuant to this Part. The advisory committee consists of the 25 
following members:  26 
1. The Commissioner of Education or the commissioner's de signee;  27 
2.  The Commissioner of Health and Human Services or the commissioner's designee;  28 
3.  One member who is a contracted service provider of early intervention and free, 29 
appropriate public education services appointed by the President of the Senate fro m a list 30 
provided by the Maine Association for Community Service Providers;  31 
4. One member who is a representative of a Head Start agency or program, 32 
representing Head Start programs in the State appointed by the President of the Senate 33 
from a list provided  by the Maine Head Start Directors Association;  34 
5. One member who is a teacher in an early childhood education program for children 35 
4 years of age that includes coordination of programs and services for eligible children 36 
within a public elementary school f rom a large school administrative unit appointed by 37 
the President of the Senate from a list provided by the Maine Education Association;  38 
6.  One member who is a principal of a public elementary school of an urban school 39 
administrative unit that has impleme nted an early childhood education program for 40 
children 4 years of age that includes coordination of programs and services for eligible 41 
children appointed by the President of the Senate from a list provided by the Maine 42 
Principals' Association;  43

Sec. VVVV -5.  Scope of the review.   The contract entered into pursuant to 28 
section 1 must require an objective evaluation of the State's early childhood special 29 
education services from birth to 5 years of age.  The evaluation must include, but is n ot 30 
limited to, comparisons between this State and other comparable states and an 31 
implementation plan for the transition of services from the Child Development Services 32 
System under the Maine Revised Statutes, Title 20 -A, section 7209 to local school 33 
admini strative units and must address the following:  34 
1. National trends and relevant models of governing and delivering early childhood 35 
special education systems in other states and jurisdictions that hold the potential for 36 
enhancing the effectiveness, efficienc y or accountability of the early childhood special 37 
education system in the State;  38 
2. The short -term and long -term costs and benefits of the proposed plan to restructure 39 
the Child Development Services System as presented to the Legislature in An Act To 40 
Reor ganize the Provision of Services for Children with Disabilities from Birth to 5 Years 41 
of Age, L.D. 1715 from the First Regular Session of the 129th Legislature;  42 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 743, L.D.  1001  
 
 Page 598 - 129LR2405(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  3. The impact that the proposed plan will have on the following:  1 
A. Current Child Development S ervices System staff, including but not limited to the 2 
potential impact on staff retirement and how any negative impact on staff retirement 3 
can be reduced or eliminated and whether Child Development Services System 4 
employees would become employees of the l ocal school administrative unit or the 5 
State;  6 
B. Current school administrative unit staff;  7 
C. The provision of services for children birth to 3 years of age; and  8 
D. Due process complaints;  9 
4. The development of recommendations for an early childhood specia l education 10 
services program plan for the State, which must include, but is not limited to:  11 
A. Models of best practices;  12 
B. Fiscally sound budget forecasting, including all possible revenue streams and 13 
updated costs;  14 
C. Transportation services;  15 
D. Data sys tems, including a billing system, a system that allows coordination with 16 
the MaineCare program and a case management documentation system;  17 
E. A timeline for the implementation of the plan under this section;  18 
F. A procedure for data collection and analysis conducted by the Maine Education 19 
Policy Research Institute;  20 
G. A method for assessing a school administrative unit's capacity for implementing 21 
early childhood special education programs;  22 
H. Training requirements for service providers and leaders;  23 
I. A publ ic information communication strategy for implementation of the plan;  24 
J. Identification of potential revisions to the Department of Health and Human 25 
Services rule Chapter 101: MaineCare Benefits Manual; and  26 
K. Workforce capacity, including but not limited to the availability of certified 27 
teachers; and  28 
5. A step -by-step implementation plan for the transition of special education services 29 
for children from birth to 3 years of age to the Department of Education and a step -by- 30 
step implementation plan for the tr ansition of special education services for children 3 31 
years of age to 5 years of age to local school administrative units, including but not 32 
limited to the resources required, both human and financial, and a detailed timeline.  33

the jails to provide funding for expenses incurred by those jails in excess of budgeted 23 
expenses actually paid or obligations incurred during fiscal year 2019 -20.  For the 24 
purpose of calculating shortfalls and unanticipated expenses, the Maine Sherif fs’ 25 
Association and Maine County Commissioners Association shall submit to the 26 
Commissioner of Corrections by June 1, 2020 signed statements of the jails’ budgets, 27 
revenues and expenditures and incurred obligations for fiscal year 2019 -20. 28 
B.  By June 7, 2 020, the Maine Sheriffs’ Association and Maine County 29 
Commissioners Association shall submit a compilation of the signed statements of 30 
the jail budgets along with the submitted financial information to the Commissioner 31 
of Corrections.   32 
C.  By July 1, 2020 , the Commissioner of Corrections shall direct that payment be 33 
made to the jails for their shortfalls and unanticipated expenses up to a total of 34 
$3,000,000.  35 
If the shortfalls and unanticipated expenses exceed $3,000,000, the payments to the jails 36 
must be reduced on a pro rata basis.  If the shortfalls and unanticipated expenses do not 37 
exceed $3,000,000, any remaining funds must lapse to the County Jail Operations Fund 38 
for use in a future year.  39

Veterans' Homes nursing facility.  Rules adopted pursuant to this section are routine 10 
technical rules as defined in the Maine Revised Statutes, Title 5, chapter 375, subchapter 11 
2-A. 12
