PART AAAAA  23 
Sec. AAAAA -1.  20-A MRSA §15688 -A, sub -§1, as repealed and replaced by 24 
PL 2017, c. 420, §8, is amended to read:  25 
1.  Career and technical education program components.  Beginning in fiscal yea r 26 
2018 -19, the allocation for career and technical education centers and career and 27 
technical education regions is based upon a model that recognizes program components 28 
that have been approved by the department pursuant to chapter 313 for:  29 
A.  Direct instr uction.  The direct instruction component includes personnel costs for 30 
teachers, education technicians for programs and clinical supervisors for health care 31 
programs.  The allocation for direct instruction is the sum of the costs as determined 32 
based on the  following components, which the commissioner shall determine 33 
annually:  34 
(1)  A teacher salary matrix.  In determining the teacher salary matrix for each 35 
program, the commissioner shall give consideration to the most recent available 36 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 743, L.D. 1001  
 
 Page 603 - 129LR2405(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  data regarding years of  education experience and years of professional work 1 
experience relevant to instructional assignment;  2 
(2)  Student -to-teacher ratios for each program;  3 
(3)  The number of education technicians required for purposes of instructional 4 
support, based on student  enrollment and program requirements.  The 5 
commissioner shall calculate the education technician allocation by multiplying 6 
the number of education technicians required by the statewide average salary for 7 
full-time education technicians, based on the most r ecent available salary data, 8 
but shall ensure that each career and technical education center or career and 9 
technical education region is allocated at least one full -time education technician; 10 
and 11 
(4)  The clinical supervision staffing level necessary for each program requiring 12 
such staffing, based on student enrollment as determined pursuant to paragraph 13 
G; 14 
B.  Central administration.  The central administration component includes personnel 15 
costs for directors, assistant directors and clerical staff workin g in career and 16 
technical education centers and career and technical education regions, as well as 17 
business managers working in career and technical education regions.  The central 18 
administration allocation is the sum of:  19 
(1)  Costs for personnel for each career and technical education center and career 20 
and technical education region, as follows:  21 
(a)  A director, the allocation for which must be for one full -time equivalent;  22 
(b)  An assistant director, the allocation for which must be based on student 23 
enrol lment as determined pursuant to paragraph G but may not exceed one 24 
full-time equivalent;  25 
(c)  Clerical staff, the allocation for which must be for at least one full -time 26 
equivalent, with additional clerical staff allocations based on student 27 
enrollment as determined pursuant to paragraph G;  28 
(d)  A career and technical education region business manager, the allocation 29 
for which must be for one full -time equivalent; and  30 
(e)  Benefit costs for employees in central administration, which must be 31 
calculated pursu ant to section 15678, subsection 5, paragraph B; and  32 
(2)  Nonpersonnel costs, which the commissioner shall calculate annually based 33 
upon the relationship of the most recent available career and technical education 34 
expenditures for nonpersonnel costs to per sonnel costs;  35 
C.  Supplies and other expenditures such as purchased services, dues and fees for 36 
instructional programs.  The allocation for supplies and other expenditures is the sum 37 
of: 38

 Page 604 - 129LR2405(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  (1)  A per -program allocation for supplies, as determined by the comm issioner 1 
based on the most recent available career and technical education expenditures 2 
amount, adjusted to the year prior to the allocation year; and  3 
(2)  A per -pupil allocation for each student in each career and technical education 4 
center and each caree r and technical education region, determined by the 5 
commissioner based on:  6 
(a)  The most recent available career and technical education expenditures 7 
amount, adjusted for inflation to the year prior to the allocation year; and  8 
(b)  Student enrollment, as d etermined pursuant to paragraph G;  9 
D.  Plant operation and maintenance, including all costs for operating and 10 
maintaining buildings and grounds.  The commissioner shall determine the allocation 11 
for plant operation and maintenance costs for each career and technical education 12 
center and each career and technical education region by multiplying the square 13 
footage of the career and technical education center or career and technical education 14 
region building by an amount per square foot, as determined by the co mmissioner;  15 
E.  Other student and staff support, which includes costs for student services 16 
coordination, career preparation, instructional technology, professional development, 17 
student assessment and program safety.  The other student and staff support 18 
allocation is the sum of the costs for:  19 
(1)  A counselor, the allocation for which must be for one full -time equivalent, to 20 
collaborate with sending school guidance counselors in order to maximize 21 
student participation at the middle school and high school gra de levels;  22 
(2)  Career and technical education center or career and technical education 23 
region student services coordinators, the allocation for which must be based on 24 
student enrollment, as determined pursuant to paragraph G, but no less than one 25 
full-time equivalent;  26 
(3)  Benefit costs for employees under this paragraph, calculated pursuant to 27 
section 15678, subsection 5, paragraph B; and  28 
(4)  Instructional technology, staff professional development, student assessment 29 
and program safety.  The commissione r shall calculate a per -pupil allocation for 30 
this allocation based upon student enrollment, as determined pursuant to 31 
paragraph G, and the relationship of the most recent available career and 32 
technical education expenditures for these costs to total costs,  adjusted to the year 33 
prior to the allocation year;  34 
F.  Equipment provided pursuant to subsection 6; and  35 
G.  Student enrollment, which is determined as follows.  36 
(1)  For each program or plan approved pursuant to chapter 313 that has 3 years 37 
of attending st udent counts on October 1st, student enrollment is a 3 -year average 38 
of the attending student counts on October 1st for that program or plan.  39 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 743, L.D. 1001  
 
 Page 605 - 129LR2405(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  (2)  For each program or plan approved pursuant to chapter 313 that is not 1 
governed by subparagraph (1), including a new program or plan approved 2 
pursuant to chapter 313, student enrollment must be based on the estimated 3 
attending student count submitted in accordance with the application for the 4 
program or plan approval.  This estimated attending student count must be  used 5 
until the program or plan has 3 consecutive years of actual attending student 6 
counts on October 1st.  7 
The In fiscal year 2019 -20, the  total allocation for a career and technical education center 8 
or career and technical education region is the sum of t he components in paragraphs A to 9 
E, except if the sum of the components in paragraphs A to E is less than the most recent 10 
expenditure data, as adjusted for inflation to the year prior to the allocation year, the 11 
career and technical education center or car eer and technical education region may not 12 
receive less than the adjusted expenditure, and if the sum of the components in 13 
paragraphs A to E is more than 5% greater than the most recent expenditure data, as 14 
adjusted for inflation to the year prior to the a llocation year, then the career and technical 15 
education center or career and technical education region may not receive more than the 16 
adjusted expenditures plus 5%.  17 
In fiscal year 2020 -21, fiscal year 2021 -22 and fiscal year 2022 -23, the total allocation f or 18 
a career and technical education center or career and technical education region is the 19 
sum of the components in paragraphs A to E, except if the sum of the components in 20 
paragraphs A to E is less than the most recent expenditure data, as adjusted for i nflation 21 
to the year prior to the allocation year, or more than the most recent expenditure data, as 22 
adjusted for inflation to the year prior to the allocation year, the total allocation must be 23 
determined pursuant to subsection 1 -A. 24 
Beginning in fiscal ye ar 2023 -24, the total allocation for a career and technical education 25 
center or career and technical education region is the sum of components in paragraphs A 26 
to E.  27 
The commissioner shall authorize monthly payment of allocations to career and technical 28 
education centers and career and technical education regions in an amount equal to 1/12 29 
of the total allocation.  Payments for satellite programs as approved pursuant to chapter 30 
313 must be made within this schedule to the responsible career and technical edu cation 31 
center or career and technical education region; it is the responsibility of the career and 32 
technical education center or career and technical education region to provide the state 33 
support for the approved satellite program to the school administrat ive unit that operates 34 
the approved satellite program.  35 
If a school administrative unit operating a career and technical education center or career 36 
and technical education region has any unexpended funds at the end of the fiscal year, 37 
these funds must be ca rried forward for the purposes of career and technical education.  38 
Sec. AAAAA -2.  20-A MRSA §15688 -A, sub -§1-A is enacted to read:  39 
1-A.  Transition period for career and technical education program components.   40 
In fiscal year 2020 -21, fiscal year 2021 -22 an d fiscal year 2022 -23, referred to in this 41 
subsection as "the transition period," the total allocation for career and technical 42 
education centers and career and technical education regions is subject to a transition 43 
period adjustment to align the total all ocation for career and technical education centers 44

program components in subsection 1.  2 
A.  In each fiscal year of the transition period, the commissioner shall identify each  3 
career and technical education center and career and technical education region for 4 
which the sum of the components in subsection 1, paragraphs A to E is less than the 5 
most recent expenditure data, as adjusted for inflation to the year prior to the 6 
alloca tion year, or more than the most recent expenditure data, as adjusted for 7 
inflation to the year prior to the allocation year.  8 
B.  In each fiscal year of the transition period, the commissioner shall calculate an 9 
adjustment to the total allocation for each career and technical education center and 10

calculation must be based on the amounts necessary to transition the career and 12 
technical education center or career and technical educ ation region to a total 13 
allocation that is equal to the sum of the components in subsection 1, paragraphs A to 14 
E by fiscal year 2023 -24.  In making this calculation, the commissioner shall ensure 15 
that the annual adjustment calculated pursuant to this parag raph is reasonably similar 16 
over the course of the transition period.  17 
C.  During each fiscal year of the transition period, the commissioner shall adjust the 18 
total allocation for each career and technical education center and career and 19 
technical education region identified pursuant to paragraph A in accordance with the 20 
calculation under paragraph B.  21 
PART BBBBB  22 
Sec. BBBBB -1.  Commission To Study Long -term Care Workforce Issues.   23 
Notwithstanding Joint Rule 353, the Commission To Study Long -term Care Workforce  24 
Issues, referred to in this section as "the commission," is established.  25 
1.  Members.   The commission consists of up to 18 members as follows:  26 
A. Two members of the Senate appointed by the President of the Senate, including a 27 
member from each of the 2 par ties holding the largest number of seats in the 28 
Legislature;  29 
B. Three members of the House of Representatives appointed by the Speaker of the 30 
House, including a member from each of the 2 parties holding the largest number of 31 
seats in the Legislature; and  32 
C. Up to 13 members who possess expertise in the subject matter of the study as 33 
follows:  34 
(1) A direct care worker appointed by the President of the Senate;  35 
(2) A provider of home -based long -term care who is a member of a statewide 36 
association representing h ome-based long -term care providers appointed by the 37 
President of the Senate;  38 
(3) A representative of a statewide association representing nonprofit housing and 39 
senior service programming appointed by the President of the Senate;  40 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 743, L.D. 1001  
 
 Page 607 - 129LR2405(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  (4) A representative of an organization providing services to individuals with 1 
intellectual disabilities and autism including employment services and long -term 2 
home supports appointed by the President of the Senate;  3 
(5) A provider of facility -based long -term care who is a member of a statewide 4 
association representing facility -based long -term care providers appointed by the 5 
Speaker of the House;  6 
(6) A representative of an organization providing statewide homemaker services 7 
through the state -funded independent support services program  within the 8 
Department of Health and Human Services appointed by the Speaker of the 9 
House;  10 
(7) A representative of an institution of higher education engaged in workforce 11 
development appointed by the Speaker of the House;  12 
(8) A representative of a service coordination agency providing service 13 
coordination to people receiving home -based and community -based long -term 14 
care appointed by the Speaker of the House;  15 
(9) A representative of an organization promoting independent living for 16 
individuals with disabiliti es appointed by the Speaker of the House;  17 
(10) A representative of a business that acts as a labor intermediary helping 18 
unemployed and underemployed people obtain employment appointed by the 19 
Speaker of the House;  20 
(11) The executive director of the long -term care ombudsman program described 21 
under the Maine Revised Statutes, Title 22, section 5106, subsection 11 -C; 22 
(12) The Commissioner of Health and Human Services, or the commissioner's 23 
designee, who may be invited to participate; and  24 
(13) The Commissioner o f Labor, or the commissioner's designee, who may be 25 
invited to participate.  26 
2. Chairs and subcommittees.  The first -named Senate member is the Senate chair 27 
and the first -named House of Representatives member is the House chair of the 28 
commission. The chairs of the commission are authorized to establish subcommittees to 29 
work on the duties listed in subsection 4 and to assist the commission. The 30 
subcommittees must be composed of members of the commission and interested persons 31 
who are not members of the commiss ion and who volunteer to serve on the 32 
subcommittees without reimbursement.  33 
3. Appointments.  All appointments must be made no later than 30 days following 34 
the effective date of this Part. The appointing authorities shall notify the Executive 35 
Director of the  Legislative Council once all appointments have been completed. After 36 
appointment of all members and after adjournment of the First Regular Session of the 37 
129th Legislature, the chairs shall call and convene the first meeting of the commission. 38 
If 30 days or more after the effective date of this Part a majority of but not all 39 
appointments have been made, the chairs may request authority and the Legislative 40 
Council may grant authority for the commission to meet and conduct its business.  41 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 743, L.D.  1001  
 
 Page 608 - 129LR2405(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  4.  Directive of comm ission.  The commission shall study and make policy 1 
recommendations in each of the following areas:  2 
A. Measuring current demand for direct care workers and projecting future needs;  3 
B. Developing a campaign and statewide recruitment strategies to encourage m ore 4 
people to work in facility -based and home -based long -term care;  5 
C.  Supporting career ladders throughout various long -term care settings;  6 
D. Identifying education needs and methods to fill education needs for direct care 7 
workers;  8 
E. Identifying barrier s to hiring and methods to overcome barriers to hiring;  9 
F. Developing strategies to improve the quality of long -term care jobs; and  10 
G. Increasing opportunities for shared staffing among long -term care providers.  11 
The commission shall make policy recommendat ions for public and private funding 12 
mechanisms to implement the commission's recommendations.  13 
5. Program.  The commission shall make recommendations for the establishment of a 14 
program that will contribute to long -term care direct care workers' postsecondary  15 
education in related fields.  16 
6. Pilot program.  The commission shall make recommendations for the 17 
establishment of a pilot program to pool part -time home care workers' hours for purposes 18 
of providing greater employment opportunity and obtaining employee be nefits.  19 
7.  Staffing.  The Legislative Council shall provide necessary staffing services to the 20 
commission, except that Legislative Council staff support is not authorized when the 21 
Legislature is in regular or special session.  22 
8.  Administration.  The Commis sioner of Health and Human Services, the State 23 
Auditor and the State Budget Officer shall provide necessary information and assistance 24 
to the commission as required for the commission's duties.  25 
9. Report.  No later than November 7, 2019, the commission shal l submit a report 26 
that includes its findings and recommendations pursuant to subsections 4 to 6, including 27 
suggested legislation, to the Joint Standing Committee on Health and Human Services. 28 
The joint standing committee may report out a bill regarding the  subject matter of the 29 
report to the Second Regular Session of the 129th Legislature.  30 
PART CCCCC  31 
Sec. CCCCC -1.  25 MRSA §5101, as amended by PL 2017, c. 407, Pt. A, §104, 32 
is further amended to read:  33 
§5101.  Substance Use Disorder Assistance Program  34 
1.  Substance Use Disorder Assistance Program.  The Substance Use Disorder 35 
Assistance Program , referred to in this chapter as "the program,"  is established to support 36 
persons with presumed substance use disorder by providing grants to municipalities and 37 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 743, L.D. 1001  
 
 Page 609 - 129LR2405(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  counties to carry out projects  programs  designed to reduce substance use, substance use - 1 
related crimes and recidivism.  2 
2.  Eligibility; program targets; programs.  Grants may be awarded to:  3 
A.  Municipal or county governments or regional jails for projects  programs  designed 4 
to assist persons with presumed substance use disorder by diverting  using liaison 5 
strategies both before and after arrest to refer  alleged low -level offenders into 6 
community -based treatment and support services.  Projects  Programs  may include, 7 
but are not limited to:  8 
(1)  Referral of program  participants in the Substance Use Disorder Assistance 9 
Program under subsection 1  to evidence -based treatment programs, including 10 
medically assisted treatment; and  11 
(2)  Provision of case management services to program  participants in the 12 
Substance Use Disorder Assistance Program under subsection 1  in order to 13 
secure appropriate treatment and support services such as housing, health care, 14 
job training and mental health services for program  participants in the Sub stance 15 
Use Disorder Assistance Program ; and 16 
B.  County governments or regional jails  for projects  programs  in county or regional  17 
jails designed to assist  facilitate the accessing by  persons with presumed substance 18 
use disorder of post -adjudication diversio n and reentry programs .  Projects  Programs  19 
may include, but are not limited to:  20 
(1)  Provision of evidence -based treatment programs, including medically 21 
assisted treatment, to jail inmates; and  22 
(2)  Provision of case management or other support services to  program  23 
participants in the Substance Use Disorder Assistance Program under subsection 24 
1 to assist in transition from jail upon release .; and  25 
C.  Municipal governments for programs designed to facilitate pathways to 26 
community -based treatment, recovery and  support services for persons with 27 
substance use disorder who present themselves to municipal law enforcement 28 
agencies and request assistance and referral to evidence -based treatment programs, 29 
including medically assisted treatment.  30 
3.  Requirements.  A grant application for a project  program  described in subsection 31 
2 must include the following:  32 
A.  A statement of purpose and measurable goals for the project  program  and use for 33 
the funds; and 34 
B.  The elements of the project  program , which must include the t argeted population, 35 
the nature of services or assistance to be provided and expected outcomes ;. 36 
C.  For diversion projects, a statement of the municipality's or county's diversion 37 
policy, including criteria for selecting participants for the project;  38 
D.  A  review of other substance use disorder services available in the applicant 39 
municipality or county and communities adjacent to the applicant municipality or 40 
county and a statement of the unmet needs to be addressed by the project;  41 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 743, L.D.  1001  
 
 Page 610 - 129LR2405(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  E.  A review of efforts t o collaborate among relevant law enforcement agencies, 1 
treatment providers, harm reduction services, recovery support services and other 2 
community resources and a summary of collaborative approaches included in the 3 
project, if any; and  4 
F.  A summary of dat a to be collected to assess the effectiveness of the project and 5 
the methodology that will be used to make that assessment.  The data to be collected 6 
must include measurements of the long -term health, treatment and criminal justice 7 
involvement outcomes for  participants and must be included in reports filed under 8 
subsection 6 as part of a rigorous evaluation process.  9 
4.  Selection of grant recipients.  The Commissioner of Public Safety shall review 10 
applications submitted by municipalities and, counties and r egional jails  for grants under 11 
this chapter.  Preference must be given to collaborative approaches that include treatment 12 
providers or community -based organizations.  The following steering committee shall 13 
advise the Commissioner of Public Safety in select ing grant recipients.  The steering 14 
committee consists of the Commissioner of Corrections or the commissioner's designee 15 
and representatives of the following organizations, programs and associations selected by 16 
the Commissioner of Public Safety from sugges tions provided by the organizations, 17 
programs and associations:  a statewide organization of police chiefs; a statewide 18 
organization of sheriffs; a statewide organization representing physicians; a statewide 19 
organization representing prosecutors; a statewi de organization representing providers of 20 
legal services for the indigent; peer recovery programs; and harm reduction associations.  21 
5.  Administration of funds.  The policy board established in this State to carry out 22 
the State's responsibilities under the  federal Justice Assistance Act of 1984, the federal 23 
Anti-Drug Abuse Act of 1986, the federal Anti -Drug Abuse Act of 1988 and the federal 24 
Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994, known as "the Justice 25 
Assistance Council," shall administer gra nt funds appropriated for use under this chapter  26 
and disburse the funds to municipalities, counties and regional jails selected under 27 
subsection 4.  The department may retain up to 5% of funds to cover administrative 28 
expenses . 29 
6.  Reports.  A recipient of a grant under subsection 4 shall report to the 30 
Commissioner of Public Safety annually on the anniversary date of the grant award 31 
regarding the status of the project  program  for which the grant was awarded.  The report 32 
must include a description of how the grant funds were spent, the results of the project  33 
program  and any recommendations for modification of the project  program , including 34 
any available information concerning the project's  program's  effectiveness in reducing 35 
substance use disorder and recidivi sm. 36 
Sec. CCCCC -2.  PL 2015, c. 481, Pt. E, §3 is repealed.  37

SUMMARY  22 
PART A  23 
 24 
This Part makes appropriations and allocations of funds for the 20 20-2021 biennium . 25 
PART B  26 
 27 
This Part makes appropriations and allocations of funds for approved reclassifications 28 
and range changes.  29 
PART C  30 
 31 
This Part establishes for fiscal year 2019 -20 the total cost of education from 32 
kindergarten to grade 12, the state c ontribution and the annual target state share 33 
percentage.  34 
PART D  35 
 36 
This Part renames the Governor's Office of Policy and Management as the Governor's 37 
Office of Policy Innovation and the Future.  38 
PART E  39 
 40 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 743, L.D.  1001  
 
 Page 612 - 129LR2405(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  This Part authorizes the Maine Governmental Facilities Authority to issue additional 1 
securities in an amount up to $55,000,000 to pay for the costs of capital repairs and 2 
improvements to and construction of state -owned facilities and hazardous waste cleanup 3 
on state -owned properties.  4 
PART F  5 
 6 
This Part revises the selection of the chair of the Revenue Forecasting Committee, 7 
beginning in calendar year 2019, to designation by the 6 members, from among the 8 
members excluding the State Budget Officer, on a rotating basis for a 2 -year term.  The 9 
exclusion is to avoid a conflict with the duties of the State Budget Officer established in 10 
current law that include convening a meeting of the Revenue Forecasting Committee if 11 
new information becomes available.  12 
PART G  13 
 14 
This Part implements background investigations for certain  individuals with a 15 
business need to receive federal tax information, in order to meet United States Internal 16 
Revenue Service standards.  This Part also expands background checks to apply to all 17 
employees of the Department of Administrative and Financial S ervices, Maine Revenue 18 
Services.  19 
This Part also corrects numerous lettering conflicts that occurred when 2 separate 20 
public laws enacted substantively different laws with the same paragraph letters.  21 
PART H  22 
 23 
This Part provides property tax relief to the resi dents of this State in the following 24 
ways.  25 
This Part sets the transfer to the Local Government Fund for state -municipal revenue 26 
sharing at 3% in fiscal year 2019 -20 and 3.75% in fiscal year 2020 -2021.  A municipality 27 
that has already established its budget  for 2019 is restricted in how it can spend the 28 
additional amount of revenue sharing received above the amount of revenue sharing 29 
assumed in that municipality's budget and the amount of revenue sharing received 30 
pursuant to this Part.  That excess revenue m ay be spent without obtaining approval 31 
through that municipality's budget process if the revenue is used for repair and 32 
maintenance of roads and bridges or for the direct reduction of the mill rate in that 33 
municipality.  34 
This Part also increases for propert y tax years beginning April 1, 2020 the value of 35 
the homestead exemption benefit under the Maine resident homestead property tax 36 
exemption from $20,000 to $25,000 and increases the state reimbursement to 37 
municipalities for the lost property tax revenue fro m 62.5% to 70%.  38 
This Part changes the formula for calculation of the property tax fairness credit to 39 
expand the credit to residents whose property taxes or rent constituting property taxes on 40 
homestead property exceeds 5%, rather than 6% in the current law , of the residents' 41 
income for tax years beginning on or after January 1, 2020.  42

PART Y  27 
 28 
This Part eliminates the Maine State Parks and Recreational Facilities Development 29 
Fund a nd the Maine State Parks Fund and replaces the 2 funds with the new Parks 30 
General Operations Fund. It also makes the Forest Recreation Resource Fund and the 31 
State Parks Improvement Fund separate units of the Parks General Operations Fund and 32 
authorizes a t ransfer of any remaining balance in these accounts to the Parks General 33 
Operations Fund account.  34

remaining balance in the Allagash Wilderness Waterway Permanent Endowment Fund 39 
account, Other Special Revenue Funds to the Allagash Waterway account, Other Special 40 
Revenue Funds in the Parks - General Operations program.  41

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 743, L.D.  1001

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  This Part authorizes a one -time transfer of all funds in excess of $500,000 from the 1 
unencumbered balance forward in the Personal Services line category in the Department 2 
of Agriculture, Conservation and Forestry, Division of Forest Protection, General Fund 3 
account to the Capital Expenditures line category in the Department of Agriculture, 4 
Conservation and Forestry, Divi sion of Forest Protection, General Fund account to fund 5 
the overhaul of existing helicopters.  6 
PART LL  7 
 8 
This Part gives the Chief Medical Examiner authority to promote immediately a 9 
Medicolegal Death Investigator I to Medicolegal Death Investigator II as lo ng as the 10 
Medicolegal Death Investigator I participates in training and education and demonstrates 11 
competencies for the higher classification.  12 
PART MM  13 
 14 
This Part authorizes the Department of Corrections to transfer, by financial order, 15 
funding in the Perso nal Services, All Other or Capital Expenditures line categories 16 
between accounts within the same fund for the purpose of paying departmental overtime 17 
expenses in fiscal years 2019 -20 and 2020 -21. 18 
PART NN  19 
 20 
This Part requires the Commissioner of Corrections to review the current 21 
organizational structure of the Department of Corrections to improve organizational 22 
efficiency and requires the State Budget Officer to transfer positions and available 23 
balances by financial order.  The authorization to make these tra nsfers is limited to the 24 
period of July 1st to December 1st of each fiscal year in the 2020 -2021 biennium.  Any 25 
transfers resulting in a mission change or facility closure must comply with the statutory 26 
requirements for legislative review.  27 
PART PP  28 
 29 
This Pa rt establishes the Maine Office of Outdoor Recreation in the Department of 30 
Economic and Community Development, Office of Tourism.  The office is headed by a 31 
director, who is responsible for strengthening Maine's outdoor recreation economy and 32 
coordinating the promotion of outdoor recreational activities in Maine with state agencies 33 
and the private sector in order to increase tourism and support statewide economic 34 
growth.  35 
PART QQ  36 
 37 
This Part does the following.  38 
1.  It requires the Department of Economic and C ommunity Development to provide 39 
staff to the ConnectME Authority and requires that staff to serve as the central broadband 40 
planning board for the State.  41 
2.  It clarifies certain responsibilities of the ConnectME Authority.  42

 6

Education.  9 
PART UU  10 
 11 
This Part increases the minimum salary for certified teachers to $35,000 in school 12 
year 2020 -2021, $37,500 in school year 2021 -2022 and $40,000 beginning with the 2022 - 13 
2023 school year.  A school administrat ive unit is required to provide the Department of 14 
Education annually the number of teachers eligible for the increase.  Based on that 15 
information, the Commissioner of Education is required to provide to each school 16 
administrative unit the funds necessary t o fund the incremental salary increases.  17 
PART VV  18 
 19 
This Part authorizes the Department of Education to enter into lease -purchase 20 
agreements for portable learning devices and support systems for students and educators 21 
for the learning technology program in f iscal years 2019 -20 and 2020 -21. 22 
PART WW  23 
 24 
This Part eliminates the language that prohibits expenditures in the Maine 25 
Environmental Protection Fund above allocations approved by the Legislature. This 26 
allows allotment increases by financial order in the Main e Environmental Protection 27 
Fund when sufficient cash is available and the allotment increase is recommended by the 28 
State Budget Officer and approved by the Governor.  29 
PART XX  30 
 31 
This Part increases from $500 to $3,500 the annual allowable reimbursement to the  32 
State Historian from the existing appropriation of the Maine Historic Preservation 33 
Commission.  34 
PART YY  35 
 36 
This Part corrects the name of the Office of MaineCare Services program as it 37 
appears in statute.  38 
PART ZZ  39 
 40

drug program from 175% to 185% of the federal poverty level.  2

 4

former Department of Mental Health and Corrections.  6 
PAR T CCC  7 
 8 
This Part repeals the law that allows the Department of Health and Human Services 9 
to administer a drug test to certain recipients of Temporary Assistance for Needy 10 
Families, or TANF, assistance and to deny TANF assistance to a person who tests 11 
posit ive for an illegal drug unless the person enrolls in a substance use disorder treatment 12 
program.  13

 15

Oversight Committee and fixes cross -references.  17

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 743, L.D.  1001  
 
 Page 620 - 129LR2405(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  This Part removes obsolete dates. This Part also repeals the provision that requires 1 
the Department of Labor, Bureau of Rehabilitation Services to maintain a legal 2 
interpreting fund to reimburse attorneys for the costs of providing interpreting or 3 
computer -assisted real -time transcription services. This Part does not change the 4 
requirements un der both state and federal law that attorneys provide qualified interpreting 5 
services when needed to represent their clients.  6 
PART QQQ  7 
 8 
This Part amends the preference in state hiring that grants an interview to a person 9 
with a disability who meets the min imum qualifications for any open position in order to 10 
comply with the federal Americans with Disabilities Act.  If the person is not selected for 11 
the position, the Department of Administrative and Financial Services, Bureau of Human 12 
Resources must provide guidance to the person regarding other available state positions 13 
for which the person might qualify.  The bureau may also refer the person to the 14 
Department of Labor, Bureau of Rehabilitation Services for vocational rehabilitation 15 
services, including oppor tunities in the special appointment program.  16 
PART RRR  17 
 18 
This Part allows the Commissioner of Labor to enter into reciprocal agreements with 19 
other states or the Federal Government to recover overpayment of unemployment 20 
insurance benefits owed in this State.  21 
PART SSS  22 
 23 
This Part allows the Commissioner of Health and Human Services in consultation 24 
with the Superintendent of Insurance to apply for a waiver of applicable provisions of the 25 
federal Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act with respect to health in surance 26 
coverage in the State for the purposes of improving affordability.  The commissioner may 27 
implement a state plan meeting the waiver requirements in a manner consistent with state 28 
and federal law, and the state plan may not increase cost sharing or r educe the 29 
comprehensiveness of coverage.  The authorization to submit a waiver expires if a waiver 30 
application has not been submitted by June 30, 2022.  31 
PART TTT  32 
 33 
This Part delays the beginning date until January 1, 2022 for changes to the 34 
experience rating  record of the most recent subject employer.  35 
PART UUU  36 
 37 
This Part modernizes laws concerning the Department of Labor, Bureau of 38 
Rehabilitation Services and the Public Utilities Commission relating to 39 
telecommunications equipment funding for the deaf and har d of hearing to reflect 40 
changes in technology and the use of such services by individuals with disabilities.  This 41 
Part repeals the requirement that a person who is certified as being deaf, hard of hearing 42 
or late deafened and whose income is less than 135 % of the federal poverty level must 43 
receive a discount of up to $10 per month in the service charge for a device used to 44

 4

COMMITTEE AMENDMENT “ A” to H.P. 743, L.D.  1001  
 
 Page 624 - 129LR2405(02) -1 
COMMITTEE AMENDMENT  This Part directs the Department of Economic and Community Development to 1 
develop a strategi c plan to recommend strategies for increased economic prosperity in the 2 
State.  This Part establishes goals for the plan and directs the department to include an 3 
analysis of gaps in funding and policy in the plan.  This Part requires that the department 4 
establish a steering committee and a work team to guide the development of the plan.  5 
This Part requires the department to report on the plan to the Joint Standing Committee 6 
on Innovation, Development, Economic Advancement and Business and provides the 7 
commi ttee permission to report out related legislation in the Second Regular Session of 8 
the 129th Legislature.  9 
PART SSSS  10 
 11 
This Part, beginning January 1, 2020, requires the Public Utilities Commission to 12 
establish the statewide E -9-1-1 surcharge and the prepaid  wireless E -9-1-1 surcharge but 13 
limits the surcharges to no more than 35¢ per month per line or number for the statewide 14 
E-9-1-1 surcharge and 35¢ per retail transaction for the prepaid wireless E -9-1-1 15 
surcharge; those amounts are 10¢ less than in the cur rent law.  This Part requires the 16 
commission to establish the surcharges by routine technical rules or through other 17 
commission proceedings.  18 
This Part, beginning January 1, 2020, also imposes a surcharge of 10¢ per month per 19 
line or number for the ConnectM E Fund and requires the ConnectME assessment and 20 
ConnectME surcharge to be collected from customers on a monthly basis.  21 
PART TTTT  22 
 23 
This Part creates the Maine Economic Development Fund as a nonlapsing fund 24 
within the Department of Economic and Community De velopment to encourage and 25 
support economic and business growth, rural manufacturing and industrial site 26 
redevelopment and implementation of a strategic plan and requires the State Controller to 27 
transfer $4,000,000 from the General Fund unappropriated surp lus to the Maine 28 
Economic Development Fund no later than June 30, 2020.  29 
PART UUUU  30 
 31 
This Part provides that it is the goal of the State to provide adequate start -up funding 32 
to ensure that public preschool programs for children 4 years of age are offered by all 33 
school administrative units by the 2023 -2024 school year and requires the Department of 34 
Education to include in its funding recommendations funding options to encourage more 35 
public preschool programs.  36 
In order to achieve this goal, this Part requires t he Department of Education to 37 
develop recommendations and report back to the Joint Standing Committee on Education 38 
and Cultural Affairs by January 1, 2020.  Recommendations must include:  39 
1. Standards for public preschool programs;  40 
2. A process for approval  and certification of programs not operated by a school 41 
administrative unit, including, but not limited to, a Head Start program or other program 42 
affiliated with the school administrative unit; and  43

recommendations in the report.  4

 6

 20

offset budget sh ortfalls.  The department, in its rulemaking, is required to determine a 24 
methodology that allocates funding in a manner that addresses the Maine Veterans' 25 
Homes shortfalls on a basis proportional to the shortfall of each Maine Veterans' Homes 26 
nursing facil ity. 27 
PART YYYY  28 
 29

nonprofit transportation company that has a written understanding with a municipality 31 
that the watercraft will be available at all times to transport an eme rgency medical 32 
services patient from an island to a licensed ambulance service on the mainland.  33

PART BBBBB  5 
 6 
This Part establishes the Commission To Study Long -term Care Workforce Issues to 7

determining the curre nt and future demand for direct care workers, methods of 9

PART CCCCC  13 
 14 
This Part amends the Maine Revised Statutes, Title 25, chapter 601, the Substance 15 
Use Disorder Assistance Program.  This Part: changes language referencing "pilot 16 
projects" to instead reference "programs"; eli minates program requirements that pertain to 17 
pilot projects; eliminates the steering committee that provides advice on the selection of 18 
grant recipients; repeals the requirement that the Justice Assistance Council disburse 19 
funds; and eliminates the authori ty of the Department of Public Safety to retain up to 5% 20 
of funds to cover administrative expenses.  21

 23

fiscal years 2019 -20 and 2020 -21 for grants for the provision of community -based 27 
treatment and support services through the Substance Use Disorder  Assistance Program.  28
